post caption: ^AI OTW: DALL-E AI

profile name: DALL-E is an AI model developed by OpenAI that's redefining creativity and the way we think about images.
DALL-E is like a digital Picasso, creating visual masterpieces from text prompts. It can dream up anything you describe and then render them into stunning images!
The creativity that DALL-E exhibits is awe-inspiring. It's not just limited to the tangible, but extends to abstract concepts, generating artwork that's nothing short of extraordinary.

Beyond the creative applications, DALL-E has potential in industries like design, fashion, and advertising, where it can instantly turn text concepts into visual prototypes. It's like having an AI artist on your team, ready to bring your ideas to life!

post caption: ^We are hiring! The UofT Branch of 180 Degrees Consulting is recruiting executives for the 2022-2023 cycle.

profile name: We are a global organization that offers affordable consulting services to social impact organizations, helping them overcome their unique challenges.

Our executive team is instrumental in this effort. They organize the high-performing teams of student consultants that underpin our work, build successful relationships with new and old clients, and run our branch with an eye toward the future.

If you‚Äôre looking to bolster your leadership skills, learn more about consulting, meet like-minded individuals outside your program and bring social impact to those who need it the most, consider applying for the following executive positions:
Our team is made up of students from all backgrounds and disciplines, so we encourage anyone who's interested to apply!
Full postings and application instructions are available here in our bio.

The application deadline is Friday, July 22nd 2022 at 11:59PM. You may apply to more than one position; if so, please rank positions by your preference in the form (you will only submit one statement of interest but make sure you answered the questions for all the positions you applied for).
We are also hosting an info session on July 19th which you can sign up for using the link in our bio.
Applications for Consulting Engagement Managers and Consultants will be open later in August.
Don‚Äôt hesitate to email us at uoft@180dc.org or message us on Instagram with any questions!^

post caption: ^180 Degrees Consulting is hosting our very own Professional Development Workshop Series to help you ace your next interview and land a summer internship in consulting!

profile name: Our workshops focus on providing students with the necessary toolkit to succeed in any type of case interview. At the end of our series, participants will have the opportunity to network with professionals from large consulting firms! ùó¶ùòÇùóØùó∫ùó∂ùòÅ ùòÜùóºùòÇùóø ùóøùó≤ùòÄùòÇùó∫ùó≤ÃÅ ùóØùòÜ ùó¶ùòÇùóªùó±ùóÆùòÜ ùó¶ùó≤ùóΩùòÅùó≤ùó∫ùóØùó≤ùóø ùü≠ùüµùòÅùóµ, ùü≠ùü≠:ùü±ùüµùó£ùó† ùóòùó¶ùóß ùòÅùóº ùóØùó≤ ùó∞ùóºùóªùòÄùó∂ùó±ùó≤ùóøùó≤ùó±. Application form is linked in our bio!

We strive to provide students with the best resources and training to help them reach their full potential. As such, our workshops are divided into five main focus areas: market sizing, profitability case, new product launch, casing math, and behavioural & networking.

Our case partner structure enables you to practice with different students for every workshop. By matching partners based on their experiences, we ensure the right people are being paired together; it is also a great opportunity to get to know like-minded people!
Visit our website for more information: https://www.180dc-uoft.org^

Our team is made up of students from all backgrounds and disciplines, so we encourage anyone who's interested to apply!
Full postings and application instructions are available here in our bio.

The application deadline is Sunday, April 18th at 11:59PM. You may apply to more than one position; if so, please rank positions by your preference in the email (you will only submit one statement of interest but make sure you answered the questions for all the positions you applied for).
Applications for Consulting Team Leads and Consultants will be open later in May.

^Wing Commander SKR Bhatt

profile name: Commissioned in 1942. His family was impoverished. He was one of three boys. One brother became a clerk. A second a teacher. SKR Bhatt attended a government school and his elder brother goaded him to finish. He always had a mechanical bent and he went to Madras to look for a job in 1941. He got a job in watch shop while he also did an Engineering course The British were starting to have emergency commissions. Bhatt joined the Air Force as an airman as they desperately needed pilots. He was selected to go to England to train to fly spitfires and hurricanes. According to his son, in Burma, he targeted ammunition dumps on Japanese boats and once when he struck Japanese boat his wing broke. He managed to land safely with two min petrol/gasoline left. Two days later he contracted malaria and was placed on sick leave. On 31st August, 1945, he had a narrow escape from Japanese soldiers who were still fighting the war despite of it being over. Post Malaria, he joined 8 Sqn Indian Air Force. There is a memorial stone in his name in the RAF association‚Äôs ‚ÄúRemember A Hero‚Äù section of the National Arboretum, Alrewas, UK‚Äù.^

post caption: ^ALPHA Education is hosting a screening of the film ‚ÄúLetters from Iwo Jima‚Äù.

profile name: Released in 2006 and directed and co-produced by¬†Clint Eastwood, Letters from Iwo Jima tells the ‚Äúthe story of the battle of Iwo Jima between the United States and Imperial Japan during World War II, as told from the perspective of the Japanese who fought it‚Äù (The Golden Globe Awards).^

post caption: ^Lt. Colonel Gopal Chakraborty

profile name: Born in Mymensingh, which used to be East Bengal, and is now part of Bangladesh.

Part of the British Army (Indian Army) during World War II, Chakraborty went to Italy serving as a doctor. He was a psychiatrist with the Indian Army, retiring as a Lt. Colonel. He took an early retirement to pursue private practice and became renowned as a psychiatrist.^

post caption: ^Major General Nanavati

profile name:
Will Lt. Colonel Nalin Kumar Dhirajlal Nanavati in a Tuxedo with his wife, Sharda Nanavati. Wearing medals.

Nalin Kumar Dhirajlal Nanavati was born in Rangoon, Burma in 1915, during the British Raj. He was a Surati Baniya from Gujarat. In World War II, he left behind a wife and a young daughter. When the family didn‚Äôt hear from him a long time, they assumed that he was killed in the war, and she remarried. But he did return to India after winning a Military Cross for bravery at the crossing of the Rivers Senio and Santerno in Italy by the 8 Indian Division during the period 9-11 Apr 1945. He also fought in the Battle of Monte Cassino. He did remarry (Sharda). He later became the military attach√© for India in Moscow. In 1963, He was sent on a non-family posting in Kashmir where he was killed at the age of 45. Other details listed on https://www.indianmemoryproject.com/144.The story on this blog is written by his granddaughter about Sharda.^

post caption: ^Ordinance Artificer W.R. Srinivasan

profile name: ‚ÄúOrdinance Artificer W.R. Srinivasan served in the Royal Indian Navy Service no. 12610 from 23/09/1942 (when he was 24 years old) to 30/11/1947. After independence from Britain, it became the Indian Navy. His time in the navy was a critical period in South Asian history and he spoke about the Navy mutiny against the British during colonial rule. He was an Ordinance Artificer. He served on various ships like HMIS Himalaya, Shamsher and Jamuna, which was the Flagship of the Navy. During World War II, he went to Bahrain, Colombo, Tigris and Euphrates. He also played football for the Naval team and was an advanced yoga practitioner. When he was getting off the ship in Mumbai, he fell into the water when he read the telegram that said that his marriage had been ‚Äúfixed‚Äù or arranged by his parents! Date of birth 15/04/1916. He passed away on 10/05/2016.‚Äù^

post caption: ^Three Members of the Women's Royal Naval Service

profile name: Photograph from Ordinance Artificer W.R. Srinivasan. Three members of the Women's Royal Naval Service.

From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_Royal_Naval_Service : "The Women's Royal Naval Service (WRNS; popularly and officially known as the Wrens) was the women's branch of the United Kingdom's Royal Navy. First formed in 1917 for the First World War, it was disbanded in 1919, then revived in 1939 at the beginning of the Second World War, remaining active until integrated into the Royal Navy in 1993. WRNS included cooks, clerks, wireless telegraphists, radar plotters, weapons analysts, range assessors, electricians and air mechanics.‚Äù^

profile name: ‚ÄúAfter World War 2 and Partition, Colonel Ilahi Baksh was the doctor to the founder of Pakistan, Muhammed Ali Jinnah. He is also the uncle of Rhode Island Pakistani American artist Saberah Malik‚Äù^

profile name: UTGSU‚Äôs LETTER TO GRAD HOUSE ‚û°Ô∏è https://bit.ly/3sox9bV

post caption: ^This month, we will be featuring photographs compiled by Professor Annu Palakunnathu Matthew at the University of Rhode Island, Department of Art and Art History.

profile name: ‚ÄúAs we mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of World War II (WWII), some participated who are barely acknowledged. Including the contributions of the two and a half million Indians who volunteered to take up arms for their British colonial rulers. This erasure is especially astonishing because WWII was truly global, with pivotal conflicts outside the European and Pacific theaters and critical battles in British India and across Asia.

The story of these soldiers has left South Asia with a complex and incomplete narrative of what happened as we gained independence from British colonial rule. These volunteers fought in the mountains of Burma, the hills of Italy, and the deserts of North Africa. They transported artillery, repaired jeeps, cooked, and, under enemy fire, carried the wounded from the battlefield to safety. Thirty of them won Victoria Crosses, England‚Äôs highest military honor, and more than eighty-seven thousand died.

These family photographs and stories come from all quadrants of South Asia. Some are from middle-class families, from royalty, and others from low-income families. Some of these soldiers were swashbuckling young men who believed in ‚Äúthe cause.‚Äù Others joined out of poverty in search of a regular meal and salary, their hunger exacerbated by the famine (created by the British) that started in Bengal and spread to other parts of India.
These are some of their stories‚Äù^

post caption: ^üö® DATE CHANGE ANNOUNCEMENT - the workshop will be happening on the 28th of January

profile name: ALPHA main will be hosting a super exciting workshop!

Participants will step into the shoes of George MacDonell and Patrick Metallic to gain a greater understanding of the Battle of Hong Kong, the POW experience, and the experiences veterans face upon returning home. George and Patrick are representatives of a greater group of soldiers who served Canada. The social-political conditions that contributed to different post-war life and the changes that have been made since are the foci of this workshop

profile name: Unniversity of Toronto Cupid's Arrow (UTCA) hosted a successful Charity Cupcake Sale for Ovarian Cancer Canada, bringing the community together to raise awareness and funds for this important cause.

Students, faculty, and members of the surrounding community gathered to sample and purchase an array of delicious cupcakesÔºõmade by local bakers and decorated with the signature teal color of Ovarian Cancer Canada. Throughout the event, attendees had the opportunity to learn about the organization's mission and ways to get involved in their efforts to support those affected by ovarian cancer.
UTCA did a fantastic job of organizing the event and creating a fun and festive atmosphere that encouraged attendees to get involved and support the cause.
With the support of the community, the event was able to raise a substantial amount of money for Ovarian Cancer Canada, which will help further their important work.
The Charity Cupcake Sale was a sweet and meaningful way to bring attention to this important cause and support those affected by ovarian cancer.^
